thread.section_title: GOV.UK departments and policy - all updates
thread.title: Corporate information: About us

title: Corporate information: About us
text:
Book an appointment to prepare a document in another language at The British Embassy Cairo 
Standard letters we provide include: Letters to facilitate local burial. You will need to provide personal identification, proof that you are the legal next of kin, death notification from doctor or hospital and the deceasedâ€™s passport For letters required by other embassies in order to get a visa to travel to their country. This includes the embassies of Saudi Arabia, Sudan, Syria, and others. Please download the Letter to Embassies free of charge which you can present at the respective embassy. For letters of no objection to help with school/university admission, please download the attached file For letters addressed to the traffic authority to help British nationals to apply for a driving/car licence, please download the attached file Legalise a document 
This service is for customers who require confirmation that the signature, seal or stamp on a document is genuine. It does not certify the authenticity of a document or give approval of its content. 
The British Embassy will only legalise documents when there is a genuine reason for them to do so. We cannot: provide services to non-British nationals where there is no link between the document and the UK certify the signature of a UK notary public 
For a UK document to be recognised in Egypt, you have to legalise it first from the Foreign and Commonwealth office then the Egyptian embassy in London . The last step after legalising the certificate/document from both places mentioned above is to stamp it from the Egyptian Ministry of foreign Affairs in Egypt. If you need the Arabic version to be legalised by the Embassy, you need to get it translated at one of our approved translators offices and submit it together with the original document stamped as explained above. 
For an Egyptian document to be used in the UK, it has to be legalised by the Egyptian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and then the Egyptian consulate in London. 
What you will need to bring with you: the document to be legalised
